description.narrative: SASK strengthens the advocacy expertise of trade unions in the Global South so that their ability to monitor workers' rights is improved. Trade unions promote fair societal development and strengthen civil society. Thus the long-term objective of the SASK programme is as follows: By 2030 the rights of men and women workers in SASK programme countries will be clearly improved.The means of SASK to achieve the goals include programme implementation in the Global South as well as communication global education and development policy advocacy in Finland. The programme focus is to improve the interest representation capability of partner organisations. Direct beneficiaries and key rights-holders are women and men working in the sectors covered by the projects as t hey will benefit directly from the improved interest representation of trade unions. Duty-bearers are government decision-makers and officials and the final beneficiaries who benefit from the rights of workers and the changes in the distribution of income in societies are working people in the programme target countries. The scope of beneficiaries also includes employees in the informal economy which are often in a very vulnerable position. The programme is human rights progressive but it also contains stro ng human rights transformative elements.The programme monitoring and result-based management system is comprehensive and holistic. The results are evaluated annually on three different levels of the result chain: output outcome impact. Programme implementa tion is monitored as planned by programme and project level indicators throughout the programme period.The main partners of SASK include based trade unions in the Global South and the international network of the labour movement. In Finland the main partne rs of SASK are the member organisations. In domestic campaigns and advocacy activities the expert networks of Finnish trade unions as well as their communication channels are a key resource. As regards the member organisations SAK and STTK are both involve d in the work of ILO and OECD thus giving SASK the opportunity to influence the policies of international organisations.
